about.title: About Me.
about.introLine1: A brand-focused designer working at the intersection of visual identity and product design.
about.introLine2: My practice centers on building brands from the ground up — from visual identity systems to product CMF, packaging, and marketing visuals — with a strong emphasis on clarity, consistency, and long-term usability.
about.introLine3: Over the past year, I've worked closely with an early-stage brand, taking part in the complete 0–1 process: establishing the brand system, and carrying it through multiple products from concept to real-world launch. Rather than creating isolated visuals, I focus on how systems perform when they are repeatedly applied, tested, and evolved in real conditions.
about.introLine4: To me, design is not just about form, but a continuous practice of judgment, structure, and long-term thinking.
about.contactIntro: Ready to start your next project?
about.contactIntro2: Whether it's a brand new idea or an ongoing project, I'd love to hear about it.
about.thankYou: Thank you for reaching out. I'll get back to you within 24 hours.
about.formDetailsPlaceholder: Please tell me about your goals, timeline, and any specific requirements...

case.projectDesc: Documenting design decisions and system evolution across different brand stages, focusing on how design maintains consistency and judgment through change.

phase-01.title: Brand Identity System
phase-01.desc: Establishing a stable and long-term usable visual foundation in the early stage when product direction is not yet clear.

intro.content: In the early stage when the brand has not yet clarified its product scale and communication methods, the primary goal is not to 'design comprehensively', but to establish a visual foundation that is stable enough for long-term use.

core-principles.title: CORE PRINCIPLES
core-principles.subtitle: Three Core Principles of the System

principles.title: Three Core Principles for System Building

clear.title: Clear
clear.desc: In uncertain environments, prioritize establishing a clear visual direction

restrained.title: Restrained
restrained.desc: Avoid over-stylization, leave room for future changes

extendable.title: Extendable
extendable.desc: All designs must consider subsequent products and communication use

logo.title: Logo design is not about formal complexity, but structural stability
logo.content: Through simple and controllable structural logic, ensure the logo maintains consistent recognition across different sizes and media.

logo-structure.title: Logo Structure Analysis
logo-structure.content: Through clear structural decomposition, revealing the internal logic and proportional relationships of the logo design.

logo-focus-lens.title: Logo Detail Focus
logo-focus-lens.content: Diving into key details of the logo, showcasing the refined considerations and craftsmanship in design.

logo-variations.title: Logo Variations Exploration
logo-variations.content: From wireframe to final form, documenting the design exploration and decision-making process.

color.title: The color system is established with long-term use as the premise
color.content: Through a limited and clear color range, ensure unified brand perception across different products and scenarios, avoiding visual fatigue caused by short-term trends.

typography.title: Typography supports information expression, not style reinforcement
typography.content: Clear hierarchical relationships ensure the brand maintains a stable reading experience across different content densities.

validation.title: After the system is established, validate through minimum applications
validation.content: These applications are not the final form, but are used to confirm the system's feasibility in real usage scenarios.

summary.title: The outcome of this phase is not a 'complete' brand
summary.content: But a visual foundation that can support subsequent product design and continue to grow through change.

phase-02.title: Product A: From Concept to Launch
phase-02.desc: The complete design process of the first product, from concept exploration to final launch.

intro.content: This is the brand's first core product, and the first time the brand visual system is applied to a real product scenario.

positioning.title: Before product design begins, clarify the boundaries
positioning.content: Which visual elements must remain consistent with the brand, and which aspects allow the product to develop its own characteristics. Product A is not an independent entity, but the first branch of the brand system.

cmf-explore.title: CMF selection is premised on long-term brand perception
cmf-explore.content: Among multiple possibilities, gradually eliminate short-term trends and over-expression, converging to a solution that meets product function while carrying brand character.

cmf-final.title: The final CMF solution emphasizes restraint and sustainability
cmf-final.content: Color, material, and finish are considered part of brand expression, not mere product decoration.

packaging.title: Packaging is the user's first interface with the brand
packaging.content: In design, packaging not only carries information, but also translates the brand system into a touchable experience.

consistency.title: At the product level, system consistency is validated for the first time
consistency.content: Even in new carriers and proportions, the brand's core recognition remains clearly established.
consistency.note: This screen proves it's 'the brand's product' rather than just 'a nice product'

realworld.title: Design ultimately faces real-world conditions
realworld.content: Under different lighting, scales, and usage conditions, the product and packaging maintain clear recognition - an important criterion for design validity.

summary.title: The completion of Product A validates the brand system's feasibility
summary.content: It's not just a product launch, but also provides clear reference for subsequent product design rhythm and differentiation control.

phase-03.title: Product B: Consistency with Variation
phase-03.desc: How the second product achieves differentiation while maintaining brand consistency.

intro.content: Building on the existing brand system and first product, the second product's design focus is no longer 'starting from zero', but how to make reasonable changes while maintaining consistency.

comparison.title: Comparison is the most direct way to judge differences
comparison.content: The two products maintain consistency in visual structure, proportion, and core language, while adjusting details according to product characteristics.
comparison.note: This screen is the 'soul' of Phase 03

consistency.title: Consistency is not a limitation, but the foundation of brand recognition
consistency.content: In Product B, core visual elements are fully preserved to ensure the brand remains clearly identifiable across different products.

variation.title: Variation is not arbitrary, but permitted by the system
variation.content: While maintaining core consistency, through subtle CMF adjustments, Product B develops its own characteristics within the product sequence.

efficiency.title: The existing system significantly improves design efficiency
efficiency.content: In Product B's design, more effort is devoted to judgment and optimization rather than repeatedly establishing basic rules.
efficiency.note: This is the signal of a mature designer

sequence.title: When multiple products are displayed together, the brand's overall image becomes clear
sequence.content: This is not just the success of individual products, but a sign that the brand system is beginning to work.

summary.title: The completion of Product B marks the brand entering sustainable expansion
summary.content: The balance between consistency and differentiation provides a stable foundation for subsequent packaging systems and marketing extensions.

phase-04.title: Packaging & Marketing Extensions
phase-04.desc: Extending the brand visual system to packaging, marketing, and more touchpoints.

intro.content: As products enter the market, brand visuals no longer exist only under ideal conditions, but need to maintain clarity and consistency across real environments and diverse scenarios.

packaging-system.title: Packaging is viewed as an important component of the brand system
packaging-system.content: As product numbers increase, through unified structure and visual logic, packaging maintains brand recognition across different specifications and information levels.

kv.title: Key visuals don't exist independently, but grow from the brand system
kv.content: Through unified visual motifs and rules, key visuals maintain consistent expression across different communication scenarios while having flexible extensibility.

regional.title: In different regions and communication contexts, visuals need moderate adjustment without losing core recognition
regional.content: The system's existence keeps these changes within controllable range.

offline.title: Real-world environments are often imperfect
offline.content: Under different lighting, materials, and spatial conditions, brand visuals maintain clarity and stability - an important test of system validity.
offline.note: This is the 'credibility anchor' of the entire case

online-offline.title: Online and offline are not two separate systems
online-offline.content: Through unified visual language, the brand forms a continuous experience across different touchpoints, rather than fragmented presentation.

pressure.title: Under complex applications and real use, the brand system maintains stable structure and clear expression
pressure.content: This marks the system as no longer just a design outcome, but sustainable brand infrastructure.

closing.title: As the system matures, design begins to truly integrate into the brand's daily operations
closing.content: The completion of this phase also provides a stable foundation for subsequent brand development.
